Adam Ewing.Action: Recognizes being out of place on an unfamiliar island but proceeds to investigate and make acquaintance with local doctor.
Trusts Doctor Henry Goose without apparent caution or critical assessment of character.
Politely introduces himself to Dr. Goose and shows respectful curiosity.
Introduces himself politely and seeks out Doctor Goose with a clear purpose.
Admits ignorance about the value of the teeth cargo without hesitation.
Swings his axe defensively to protect his two sons from attackers.
Swings his axe defensively to protect himself and his sons from attackers.
Lose possession of his axe when it is torn from his hands.
Is overcome and ultimately killed by the attackers, unable to effectively repel or evade them.
Successfully completes a formal contract signing despite recent failing health, demonstrating perseverance and responsibility.
Appears somewhat submissive or overshadowed by his father-in-law's presence, indicating a possible lack of assertiveness or confidence in his own standing.
Provides a thoughtful, clear explanation of a complex philosophical/religious work, demonstrating intellectual engagement and confident speech.
Feels nausea and faints witnessing the brutal whipping and suffering of the victim
Unable to turn away from the suffering man, showing empathy and recognition of pain
Expresses deep gratitude and calls Goose 'as precious to me, my friend, as any diamond.'
Acknowledges his vulnerability openly when receiving medicine and appreciates the doctor’s help.
Acknowledges Raphael's concern with appreciation despite his own discomfort.
Expresses understanding that Raphael is not at fault for the cabin arrangements.
Unaware of Dr. Goose’s malicious intent and conspiracy against him.
Prays earnestly despite physical pain and distress, showing persistence and seeking strength.
Appears physically weak and troubled by visions and pain, possibly impairing his judgement and actions.
Shows initial fear but listens to Autua's plea for help, acknowledging the man's situation.
Refuses to help Autua escape, citing it is not his responsibility and denies involvement despite knowing the man’s danger.
Expresses distrust or disapproval towards D’Arnog and the idea of helping an escaped slave, showing reluctance to intervene.
He cautiously listens to Autua, evaluates the situation, but ultimately refuses to help him, citing practical limitations and his role as a merchant ship officer.
Fails to empathize with Autua’s plight or take initiative to help despite clear moral implications, showing reluctance to intervene or take risks.
Blocks his door with a barrel to protect himself, then offers food to Autua, the runaway slave.
Shows concern by asking Autua why he was being whipped so savagely.
Expresses distrust and emphasizes the legal and social gap between them: 'You're a runaway slave. I'm a lawyer. How do you imagine we could possibly be friends?'
Politely greets a grumpy superior despite hostility.
Defends the Moriori stowaway and emphasizes his innocence and victimization, showing concern for the oppressed.
Intervenes on behalf of Autua, promises to speak to the Captain and trusts in the Captain's fairness.
Advocates for Autua, attempts to intervene on his behalf with the Captain, demonstrates a willingness to speak up against mistreatment.
Places trust in the Captain being a fair man despite visible evidence to the contrary and the crowd’s unease.
Opposes Captain Molyneux's order to shoot Autua, saying 'No! You can’t do this!'
Shows fear and hesitation when Autua is tested by Captain Molyneux, revealing doubts about Autua's honesty but does not intervene effectively.
Attempts to stop Boerhaave from shooting Autua, demonstrating moral courage and quick reaction in a tense situation.
Pleads with the captain to intervene and stop Boerhaave from harming Autua, showing visible turmoil and helplessness.
Attempts to physically interfere to protect Autua from Boerhaave, risking his own safety.
Allows his wedding ring to become so tight that it cuts off circulation and requires removal.
Expresses distress at losing the wedding ring, showing emotional attachment but no practical foresight.
Expresses horror and helplessness when confronted by Goose's racism and hostility.
Begged to keep a black man away from him, reflecting racial prejudice.
His mouth works uselessly in shock, showing vulnerability rather than aggression or rejection.
Allows Autua to intervene and protect him from Goose's attack.
Does not retaliate against Goose after being poisoned and attacked.
Spits out poison after being attacked before it takes lethal effect.
Depends on others (Autua) to protect and save him from danger.
No direct action or statement by Adam Ewing in the excerpt; omission of involvement in plans or problem-solving.
Refuses to participate in slave trade by resigning and burns contract, standing up for his moral convictions despite personal cost.
Acknowledges the support of his wife who demonstrates solidarity by waiting outside in the carriage.
Uses a cane and appears physically vulnerable but acts with courage and sincerity.
Insists on attending to urgent matters despite illness, showing determination and prioritization.
Publicly destroys a business contract on moral grounds, risking his job and financial security, demonstrating conviction and moral clarity.
Handles confrontation with father-in-law calmly and confidently, presenting his resignation without hesitation.
Acts on conscience rather than financial or social pressure, indicating personal integrity over pragmatism.
Expresses desire to shape a better world for his son, despite warnings about societal risks.
Acknowledges that each individual effort is part of a greater whole by saying 'what is any ocean but a multitude of drops?'
Expresses determination to shape a better world for his son despite social risks and warnings.
Engages in idealistic dialogue but does not show specific practical plans or actions here.
Explains his father-in-law's work on 'The Ladder of Civilization' with sincerity and in a calm manner, engaging with the group.
Uses his cane to jam the elevator doors open and prevent them from closing on Luisa.
Says he will remain seated after the elevator stops suddenly, being cautious in case it restarts unexpectedly.
Does not offer to call for help or actively assist beyond staying seated and accepting help from Luisa.
Acknowledges quarantine without resistance and tries to rest despite discomfort.
Allows provisions to be placed in his cabin with polite acceptance, showing calmness and social grace.
Does not challenge the doctor’s decision about quarantine despite having contrary knowledge (Henry argued it’s not contagious).
Refuses to help Autua who threatens to kill himself unless Ewing attacks others, showing hesitation and confusion.
Fails to recognize the seriousness of signing custody and residency papers; mistakes hotel registry for legal documents.
Attempts to assert control by demanding keys back and insisting on calling a cab; verbally confronts staff despite rules.
Allows Autua to stay with him during critical illness despite others' objections
Shows physical weakness and requires assistance with treatment, appearing semi-conscious and unable to act decisively.
Requests others to see who knocks and does not resist intrusion despite his critical condition, showing limited control over the situation.
His condition is serious but he remains aware enough to respond briefly to Autua, showing some mental presence despite physical impairment.
Stands up despite weakness and swings the metal lock box to defend Autua from Goose's attack.
Rises to his feet despite being told he cannot stand, then uses a metal lock box as a weapon to strike down Goose, effectively defending himself and others.
